4. I've heard people make this case against academia often. People make it, I guess, because the point is meant to be to figure out truth, and yet academica falls short of the mark.

Yet in my own experience working in industry, at least in academia people *try* to figure out the truth. IME it can be hard to even explain to engineers outside academia that you shouldn't form strong conclusions with too few data, or that cherry picking can bias results. In academia it is taken for granted that such things are bad, even though they do occur.

"Yet in my own experience working in industry, at least in academia people *try* to figure out the truth. IME it can be hard to even explain to engineers outside academia that you shouldn't form strong conclusions with too few data, or that cherry picking can bias results. "

Sounds reasonable and rational but is (also) a bit illustrative for the average academic. Its not that in industry people are impatient (relative to academia) because they are short-sighted or dumb, its because time has an (opportunity) cost in competitive markets and not (so much) in academia.

I am sure that in industry people sometimes cut too many corners, however making things too complicated and too convoluted has its own costs.

item.title: Comment on Sunday assorted links by mkt42
item.description:
"1. Claims about social resilience (NYT)."

This brings to mind a couple of concepts.

Though Taleb is more of a crank than insightful, "anti-fragile" is a good way to summarize the resilient cultures. The ones that developed anti-fragile infrastructures and mechanisms survived, or at least bounced back faster.

I'd guess that there are analogies here with the evolution of species within given ecological niches? If the local area stays stable, the local organisms can evolve to maximize their survival and reproduction in that niche; maybe they're the resident orca pods in Puget Sound that specialize in eating salmon, that used to be plentiful there.

Which is great while it lasts, their salmon-eating lifestyles helped them thrive over less-specialized species.

But Puget Sound in the 21st and late 20th century has a lot less salmon (and more pollution and boat traffic) and the local orca population is threatened -- while transient orca pods that wander in and out of Puget Sound, and that do not limit themselves to eating salmon, are doing fine.

In a changing ecological environment, the anti-fragile orca populations are doing better. In a stable one, the resident population thrived.

The other concept that might be relevant here is the agriculture-versus-hunter-gatherer article that Tyler linked to a couple of weeks ago. If your region is subject to frequent disruption, you're better off having technologies and lifestyles -- such as agriculture -- that enable you to ride out those tough times.

With more reliable weather, local game, and local plants, you might instead benefit from the higher average productivity of the hunter-gatherer lifestyle. But now you're more vulnerable to changes in climate or severe weather or even just seasonality.

item.title: Comment on U.S.A.-India fact of the day by M
item.description:
Reply to Naveen K:

But population size doesn’t correspond to success in any field. Indians are notoriously terrible at movies and peak scientific achievements despite making a lot of movies and being a lot of scientists.

So Indians being over-represented in CEOs deserves looking into and they’re doing something right here.

Indians are over-represented and under-achievers (not talented enough or doing something wrong) in many other fields despite being 18% of the world population. Indians make 25% of all movies each year and they’re the among the worst movies made in the world. Plus they’re severely under-represented in Nobel prizes.

Percentage of world population that is Muslim: 24%
Indian: 18%
Percentage that is Jewish: 0.2%

Number of Nobel Prizes in science, medicine, and economics awarded to Muslims: 4
Indians: 9
Jews: 189

The sort of reasoning of using prize winners as some estimate of population ability in "natural talent" is very bad though. Take Satyendra Nath Bose.

Do we take the view that he was some incredible once-in-a-century outlier of Indian "natural talent" who just happened to occur when he did? Or that he benefitted from a lot of being in the right proximity to the right research networks, at the right time, and there are plenty of people in India with equal natural talent?

And if we take a view closer to the latter, IMO a more sensible view, then we must bear in mind that we must apply it across the board.

These network effects are IMO why the estimation of any population ability level from some prize is a bad idea. No, Jewish Israelis are not worse at math than we think from their (mediocre) PISA scores because they have not very impressive performance in the International Mathematical Olmypiad (compared to, say, Romania). No, Israelis are not great at math because they have higher performance in Fields Medals than their PISA scores would suggest. Etc.

item.description:
Reply to M:

The sort of reasoning of using prize winners as some estimate of population ability in "natural talent" is very bad though. Take Satyendra Nath Bose.

Do we take the view that he was some incredible once-in-a-century outlier of Indian "natural talent" who just happened to occur when he did? Or that he benefitted from a lot of being in the right proximity to the right research networks, at the right time, and there are plenty of people in India with equal natural talent?

And if we take a view closer to the latter, IMO a more sensible view, then we must bear in mind that we must apply it across the board.

These network effects are IMO why the estimation of any population ability level from some prize is a bad idea. No, Jewish Israelis are not worse at math than we think from their (mediocre) PISA scores because they have not very impressive performance in the International Mathematical Olmypiad (compared to, say, Romania). No, Israelis are not great at math because they have higher performance in Fields Medals than their PISA scores would suggest. Etc.

"Do we take the view that he was some incredible once-in-a-century outlier of Indian "natural talent" who just happened to occur when he did?"

Just from reading his wikipedia, he seems to have benefited a lot from contacting Einstein regarding his discoveries and from Einstein's recognition of the importance of his work.

I wouldn't say the distribution of Nobels reflects population *ability*, but it probably *does* reflect national investment in science (physics labs and equipment is expensive), which in turn plays back into what researchers are able to investigate and the kinds of things they specialize in.

A line in the Wikipedia article you referenced may elude to India having very limited funds for physics research:

"[Bose] insisted every student design their own equipment using local materials and local technicians. "

Wow! On the one hand, people surely have to be very bright, creative and resourceful to build their own equipment from local materials! On the other, surely this is very limiting as to the kinds of research people can do. It suggests that there was virtually no investment in physics research on the part of the government - probably not much of a surprise given that, at the time, India was poor and hungry.

So the distribution fo prizes may not measure ability, but it could be very roughly relevant to productivity.
